de.esoco.lib.expression.monad

Interface Monad<T,M extends Monad<?,M>>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Functor<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Call, Option, Promise, Try

    public interface Monad<T,M extends Monad<?,M>>
extends Functor<T>
    Interface of a Functor extension that provides the monadic method flatMap(Function) for transformation into derived monads. The generic monad type has been relaxed to Monad<?,M> because otherwise the generic declaration of monadic methods like flatMap(Function) would not be possible with Java's type system. Subclasses therefore need to declare their own type at that position with a wildcard parameter, e.g. SubMonad<T> extends Monad<T, SubMonad<?>>. This type is not further exposed in the API and is only needed for the type hierarchy to work.

    • Method Detail

      • flatMap

        <R,N extends Monad<R,M>> Monad<R,M> flatMap(java.util.function.Function<? super T,N> fMap)
        Maps this instance into another monad by applying a mapping function to the enclosed value that produces the new monad. Implementations should override the return type to their specific type because the Java type system provides no way to generically define the method return type needed for this case.
        Parameters:
        fMap - The monad mapping function
        Returns:
        The mapped and flattened monad

      • and

        default <V,R,N extends Monad<V,M>> Monad<R,M> and(N rOther,
                                                  java.util.function.BiFunction<? super T,? super V,? extends R> fJoin)
        Combines this monad with another monad into a new monad of the same type. This is done by invoking flatMap(Function) on this instance and "lifting" the other monad by invoking it's map(Function) method. Therefore this type of method is sometimes also called "lift" or "liftM2".

        Implementations should override this method to return their own type but they can simply invoke the default implementation ( Monad.super.and(rOther, fJoin)) and cast the result to their own type. The explicit declaration in subclasses is necessary because of the limitations of Java's generic type system.

        Parameters:
        rOther - The other monad to combine with
        fJoin - A binary function that joins the values of both monads
        Returns:
        The new joined monad

      • map

        <R> Monad<R,M> map(java.util.function.Function<? super T,? extends R> fMap)
        Redefined here to change the return type to Monad. Subclasses can typically implement this by invoking their flatMap(Function) and declare their own type as the return type.
        Specified by:
        map in interface Functor<T>
        Parameters:
        fMap - The value mapping function
        Returns:
        A mapped functor
        See Also:
        Functor.map(Function)

      • then

        default Monad<T,M> then(java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> fConsumer)
        Redefined here to change the return type to Monad. Subclasses can typically just invoke super and declare their own type as the return type.
        Specified by:
        then in interface Functor<T>
        Parameters:
        fConsumer - The consumer of the wrapped value
        Returns:
        The resulting functor for chained invocations
        See Also:
        Functor.then(Consumer)
